contentrichtext.text: {{Use dmy dates|date=December 2010}} {{one source|date=February 2012}} {{no footnotes|date=February 2012}} '''Henry Sampson Woodfall''' (21 June 1739 – 12 December 1805) was an English printer and journalist. He was born and lived in [[London]]. His grandfather, Henry Woodfall (''c.'' 1686 – 1747), was the author of the ballad ''[[Darby and Joan]]'', for which John Darby and his wife were the originals; HS Woodward's grandfather Woodfall had been apprenticed in 1701 to Darby, a printer in Bartholomew Close in the [[Little Britain, London|Little Britain]] area of London, who died in 1730.<ref>{{cite DNB|wstitle=Woodfall, Henry Sampson}}</ref> The grandfather Woodfall printed many of the works of [[Alexander Pope]].<ref>{{cite journal|title=Pope and Woodfall|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=ybIRAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA377|date=19 May 1855|journal=Notes and Queries|pages=377-378}}</ref> HS Woodfall's uncle George was a bookseller in Charing Cross. HS Woodfall's father, Henry Woodfall (1713 – 1769), was the printer of the newspaper the ''[[Public Advertiser]]'', and HS Woodfall was [[apprenticeship|apprenticed]] to his father. At the age of nineteen, HS Woodfall took over the control of the ''Public Advertiser''. In it appeared, between 21 January 1769 and 21 January 1772, the famous letters of "[[Junius]]."<ref>{{cite book|title=Junius|author=Wade, John|chapter=Preliminary Esssay|year=1890|volume=vol. 1|location=London|publisher=George Bell & Sons|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=_3MNAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA1}}</ref> In December 1769 Woodfall published a potentially actionable "Letter to the King" by Junius that brought legal charges against Woodfall and five others; Woodfall's case went before a jury in June 1770 but was dismissed in November 1770.<ref>{{cite book|author=Lee, Anthony W.|chapter=The Education of Henry Sampson Woodfall, Newspaperman|title=Mentoring in Eighteenth-Century British Literature and Culture|year=2010|publisher=Ashgate Publishing|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=6SAT3TjE4R0C&pg=PA163}}</ref> Woodfall sold his interest in the ''Public Advertiser'' in 1793. His son George Woodfall (1767 – 1844) was also in the family printing business.<ref>{{cite DNB|wstitle=Woodfall, George}}</ref> HS Woodfall's younger brother, [[William Woodfall]] (1746–1803), a journalist, established in 1789 a daily paper called the ''Diary, or Woodfall's Register'', in which, for the first time, reports of [[Parliament of England|parliament]]ary debates were published on the morning after they had taken place.<ref>{{cite journal|chapter=obituary notice for William Woodfall|title=Monthly Magazine and British Register|year=1803|page=280|volume=vol. 16|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=AFIoAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA280&lpg=PA280}}</ref> ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *{{worldcat id|lccn-nr2001-6852}} *{{1911|wstitle=Woodfall, Henry Sampson}} {{Authority control|VIAF=76752238}} {{Persondata <!-- Metadata: see [[Wikipedia:Persondata]]. --> | NAME = Woodfall, Henry Sampson | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = English journalist | DATE OF BIRTH = 21 June 1739 | PLACE OF BIRTH = | DATE OF DEATH = 12 December 1805 | PLACE OF DEATH = }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Woodfall, Henry Sampson}} [[Category:English printers]] [[Category:English journalists]] [[Category:1739 births]] [[Category:1805 deaths]] [[Category:Writers from London]] {{England-writer-stub}} {{UK-painter-stub}} {{UK-journalist-stub}}
